posts.com:
>'Robotic' and depressed
IME, the key to avoid seeming 'robotic' (ime, at least), is to open up and communicate clearly about what is going on inside your head, what you are feeling, why you are feeling it, and what can be done to make things better for you - specifically, what THEY can do to help.
As the partner of a person who is depressed, it's also important to ask questions until you understand how they're feeling. It's also important to actually LISTEN to them and try to hear them out - not just argue or say 'you're not making sense'.

Tbh it sounds like both of you probably struggled to communicate clearly about this issue. But it also sounds very much like she only brought it up when it was too late - just to hurt you, and to shift the guilt of cheating on to you, to make herself feel 'cleaner'. It's a dick move. It's good to work on the issue, but I don't think it's anywhere NEAR something that would inspire cheating. So idk, that's something to think about, I hope?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28024075
>I follow these generals to get an idea of what I'm competing against
You don't compete against aything but your past life. Every improvement that you make is a win.

You want friends and hobbies? Not easy when you are out of school and working fulltime, but not impossible. These three steps should get you started. Important is, that you set SMART goals for everyone of them.

Step 1: Try any hobby that is easily available in your area. No matter what. Even if you don't like it, you will have some experience gathered from that. GOALS: Until end of March you will have tried out 3 different hobbies. Two of them you visited at least twice. No excuses.

Step 2: Think of old friends or loose acquaintances that you like. Try hanging out with them. GOALS: Until end of March you will have spoken (person or phone) to 3 old contacts as well as texted 3 different persons. You ask them to do any activity togehter, maybe one of your new hobbies? You can also meet with distant family. Someone not picking up the phone is not an excuse

Step 3: Read a book on social cues "how to win friends and influence people" is often recommended. Finish it until end of March. No Excuses.

After doint this you should be able to stand on your own feet. It won't be easy. In fact there is a good chance, that you will feel like a weirdo outcast for years to come, but it does get easier. I speak from experience.

If you go up to someone and say they looked interesting / cute and wanted to meet them, 90% of the time they're going to be flattered, not annoyed. Even if they reject you, they're going to be polite about it generally and be impressed you were confident enough to make the move. ANd if they're rude, they were mean people anyway. The worst you can get is someone saying no and moving on with your day.

People who don't approach think the reaction is going to be much harsher than it generally is.

It's called day game / cold approach. Read up on it and watch videos and see how it actually generally goes.

>>28031368
>I know my first approach will be bad. I want to overcome that fear.
Dip your toes in by talking to strangers about things - asking them about the weather, or what aisle you can find things.

The only real tip is look good and live where the attractive women are; because it's just a numbers game. Only 1 in several hundred are willing to hold a conversation with a strange flirty guy, then answer his texts, then meet him for drinks or some other activity a few times, and then sleep with him. Basically, the point of daygame is to learn how to recognize "Yes" girls and feel confident in your ability to flirt - it's a total waste of time to make your primary pipeline for dating women, but there are marginal situations where a girl makes eye contact or you start talking and hit it off really well, where you switch into "approach mode". Overall, it's retarded, especially outside of the half-dozen or so cities where the hot girls are out and about - but as a skill, it really helps you on the margins when you aren't actively patrolling and trying to hit on girls.

Street approach has been dead since the every chick in poor countries got a shitty Android and IG account.

>boyfriend
Politely excuse yourself, or if you're a true degenerate escalate to "Well, he's not here, is he?"

>not interested in dating
Politely excuse yourself, say you had fun talking to her. This is a firm, but polite "No." Press forward at the risk of a public blowup.

Get a job in retail, preferably sales like best buy etc. A job that requires you to interact with people. The key to being a good listener is to simply assume the person you're talking to can teach you stuff and has information you haven't come across yet. You can say you did something at your old job if you have the skills to do it, as your new employer won't be able to verify much with your old employer. Be careful when doing this though.

there's no reason to be humble or brutally honest on your own resume, even if you view it as morally repugnant. All that does is shoot yourself in the foot, while some other guy will get away with it.

word-smith your resume to fit your new job, but don't do it to excess. You want to get it through the clueless HR-great filter that gets rid of most the applicants, but you don't want the engineers/others actually interviewing to start asking you specifics about shit you bullshitted about too much. Don't grossly lie, but don't sell things short. If all you did is data entry for a job, you could easily lie and start exaggerating about your server/sql/database experience and coding experience for cleaning up junk data. those things go hand in hand. If you are knowledgeable of them, you can bullshit it easily - but chances are you'd be building upon stuff you worked on. easier to bullshit as you get more experience, but the catch-22 is just getting that initial foot in the door.

>Clinically-depressed bros, how do you cope when you have no interest in anything?
I go to the doctor and got meds! Now, the depression is still there but the physiological effects of it are completely cut off. Before meds when I was depressed, I felt like doing nothing, my interests disappeared, I felt numb and void and (this is the important part) my body felt this way too. I was lethargic, hard to concentrate, it was physically difficult to move, etc. My body matched my mind.

After meds, the mental effects were still there. I will still wake up and think, "I don't want to get up," but if I can overcome that mental block my body is full of energy. I can actually GET UP physically and go. I'm not lethargic. My body works.

Meds won't "cure" depression... but it sure is fucking nice to be able to kick start my brain and have my body respond with energy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
sleeping excessively - my dreams seem to be the only place that I can be happy/fulfilled, even if I rarely remember them. it's basically an escape from my current reality.
working extra shifts and hours - if I am too tired and busy, I cannot ruminate about the issues in my life. I am forced to live in the present, and my only concern becomes the immediate. In the end, all this does is accrues me money for a future I don't really care to see.
exercise - lifting and things. gives me somewhat a sense of control over one aspect of my life, and I can improve myself, even if it's not addressing the root issues in my life.
attempting to escape into vidya, but I find that increasingly works less and less. Ultimately, I'll escape into a sandbox type game more often than not, where I can create an idealized self or idealized reality (eg. making self in Sims and falling in love/starting a family with someone, etc). This is another escape from reality, that I quickly grow disinterested in more and more now that I am older. Worked well in my teens and most of twenties.

Ultimately, I've just learned to live with it. I try not to worry about the elements in my life that I cannot control even if I acknowledge they suck. I simply try to focus on the small things that I can control. I still will likely off myself in years time, but I keep hoping that if I make small improvements to my life over time perhaps something will change for the better. I do the things I hate doing, only to realize they aren't that bad. I try to establish good habits, so that even if I fall deeper into the pit that is depression it's not going to be readily apparent that I am at rock bottom. I trudge along, waiting to meet someone or for some element to change in my life. Nothing ends up bringing fulfillment, but I keep going along anyway with that faint hope that maybe something in the future might reignite something in my mind. Constant search for greener grass. It's all I can do really.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28036280
It depends on the task but the best thing to do is make a plan for the task and break it up into sections. I ran a marathon in Oct 20, just was sick of being depressed and had it on my bucket list so woke up and ran one day. How I committed to that run was I made multiple music playlists that I knew would motivate me, I called a friend and told him I was about to do it, and I also set 30 minute timers-- when they ended I would assess whether I would keep running, walk, take a break, etc and then I'd start a new 30 min timer when I furred out what I was doing. The final thing, and the most important one is figuring out how to make yourself become hyperfocused. For me on that it involved me constantly saying I'm going to finish the marathon no matter what, and that a lifetime of fucked up legs is better than a lifetime of wanting to run a marathon and never doing it.

Tl;dr: just do it, and once you start don't stop until it's done, no matter what.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28036297
yeah I'm not an expert on your situation but I expect both a therapist and meditation would help.

to your question about how to accept anxiety, yeah it's actually kind of like that: (''anxiety I accept you"). its called mindfulness its the essence of meditation (at least some meditation types). observe your thoughts and feelings without judging them. let them be what they will be. don't resist the unpleasant feelings, just watch. this will make them have less power over you. doing the same thing in written format can also help. write down the thoughts and feelings you observe.

anti-anxiety drugs can be very effective but personally I would prefer to try other methods first before chemicals or you will learn to need a crutch. benzodiazepines (xanax, klonopin, valium) for example work really well but they can be addictive and will fuck up your brain if you take them for too long.

posts.sub: How do I stop being jealous of my stepdaughter?
posts.com:
I need some voices of reason here. I feel ridiculous but I get incredibly jealous of my 11 year old stepdaughter when she cuddles/hangs on my husband. Here’s some context:

So I came into my stepdaughter's life when she was 7. We get along fine but I remember even at that point having an intense feeling of jealousy one day when I came in and saw her and my husband spooning on the couch, taking a nap together. It should’ve been sweet and cute to me, but it made me feel awful. Most of the time they never cuddle, it’s usually limited to hugs and hand holding and tickling, so when the cuddling happens it feels out of place from what I’m used to seeing between them.

It gets waaay worse when we are around others, almost like they are putting on a “show” of affection for the audience. Recently, my father in law stayed with us over Christmas for a few days and the ENTIRE time it’s like they couldn’t peel off of each other. Every time I turned around she was draped over his lap, hugging onto his arm and constantly (like every 15 minutes at times) saying “Daddy? I love you.”

It should be sweet, I should think it’s cute and be happy they have a sweet relationship. It’s just so off putting to me especially when it doesn’t happen 85 percent of the time. And man, I’m so jealous! I want my husband to give me some of that attention when it’s happening and it legit feels like he’s hugging onto another woman sometimes, despite my brain screaming at me that I’m being a terrible person for feeling that way. And it makes me feel weird when I try to hold his hand or touch him in any way when he’s in that mode with her because I almost feel like I’m intruding on something.

What can I do to get over this? My solution when this happens is to keep it to myself and act like nothing is wrong because I would feel so awful saying a word of this to my husband. It bothers me so much that I can’t just look at them and think it’s cute.

>>28035450
>what's wrong with that statement?
Not that guy, but it's simply false, both on factual and practical ones.

There were national scandals (in the US) even in the 1800s about age gaps, and they were far more virulent against what we'd call underage marriages today (the outrage against specific cases being a major reason why the minimum age of marriage was raised across the country). The median age of marriage of women in the West has almost never gone below 20 for as far back as we have reliable records, and marriages the minimum legal age of were in practice very rare outside of the aristocracy of Europe. It was even more rare to have large age gaps with a bride at that minimum.

And even if there were historical precedent for large age gaps being a norm, that doesn't make it a good idea if you're trying to get into a lasting and loving marriage. Age gaps of over a decade (and very young bridal ages) carry a greatly increased chance of divorce, as much as 50% more. Two decades, and the chances of divorce are doubled. Unless your idea of a "good" marriage is a guy cycling through young wives like Dicaprio does with his girlfriends, large age gaps clearly aren't a winning strategy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I did 8 months homeless, then later another 4 months.

if you can avoid the shelters and find somewhere quiet to park your virgin butthole at night, homelessness is almost tolerable. especially if you get a gym membership and shower there. laundry is a bit of a problem. food isnt really a problem as missions and churches in any city give out food. plus homeless people get food stamps from their state health / family department.

the problem is getting money. you can do day labor jobs which means showing up at 5 am and sitting in a dumpy shithole with a bunch of burned out crackheads and alcoholics and hoping your name gets called for minimum wage work. you can do online work like amazon MTurk. Sit at the library getting warm or staying cool and get you $50-90 bucks a week.

The main thing I learned is that its hard to get a stable sleeping area. In an urban environment its hard to sleep outdoors unless you wander to the edge of the city limits. All the government buildings and businesses hire security to drive though multiple times a night and clear out the homeless sleeping there. I think its worth a shot if youre just done with your current life. Pick a city that has homeless benefits and go

Having zero money is awful. Sure, you dont have to worry about work deadlines or rent, but at the same time you smell McDonalds on the wind and cant afford a hamburger. You pass a liquor store and cant afford a bottle. You cant afford shit. Sometimes you cant even afford a city bus ticket. Gotta find a way to get money.

The great irony of homelessness is you have all the time to yourself. No responsibilities. And yet it's harder to get money. You will find that you are broke most of the time. Nobody will hire a filthy piece of shit who stinks, carrying a backpack around.

Do you have family members or friends you could crash with for a little bit? Like 2 weeks to a month on the couch? I mean we're in a job crisis too right now, so it's not that hard to find a decent position moderately above minimum wage that'll train you on site rather than require a degree. Your savings will cover security deposit on a place and at least a month of rent, if they give you shit for having no credit or cosigner, scrounge up another month of rent to put down. GTFO of Oregon, it's a shithole for living cost and homelessness is horrible there for a reason. Try Idaho or Nevada or even Washington. Apply for a job in another state, and start searching for an apartment, tell the employer and landlord you are moving to said city and you should be able to nail a job and a place to go to before you even get there.

You could look into being a flight attendant, lots of open positions that make decent pay, you'd have places to sleep. They might cover some basic expenses working there idk you'd have to research it. I worked for Valvoline as a technician for a while and they had great programs to move and keep your job in another city/state, coed staff, good pay, and the job was easier than you'd think. I was able to make it work as a renter paying ~$650/mo too. Not in Oregon tho lol.

You can use gym memberships to shower and exercise, your pay right now could tide you into a new job by paying for food and toiletries to clean yourself at said gym, and give you enough time to funnel absolutely all of your excess money after basic expenses into savings, which will help you build a launchpad to get back up. They have wall outlets for charging shit, laundromats too. Plenty of those places have microwaves for food as well.

Don't drag your feet. I'd be looking for a higher paying job like my life depended on it if I were in your position. You don't want to be homeless at all, especially as a woman.

Good luck, I mean it. I hope you figure this shit out.

For me it helps to take note of all the shit I’ve worried about and sent me into a spiral that ended up either not happening at all or not being a big deal. With that sort of knowledge I can usually convince myself, correctly, that I’m not worrying about a real problem. If you don’t have previous things you’ve worried about that ended up being not a big deal, let this be the first one when things inevitably work out.

Additionally, I spent a few years after high school as a merchant sailor. Here’s two bits of sailor wisdom that have helped me in life.

Number 1, any problem that cannot directly result in you, or someone else, being killed, maimed, imprisoned or homeless is not a big deal.

Number 2, if you don’t know the knot, tie a lot. If you’re really worried about your future because you don’t have another job lined up, start applying now as much as you can. You’ll find something eventually.

Atheism is a perfectly valid stance to take if you have gone through the critical process to rationalise it.
Nowadays too many people claim to "not believe in god" because they can't be bothered with it, or because they think the church is lame. This is arrogant, and leaves alot of deeply profound questions unanswered, which will cause the sort of distress OP is experiencing right now.
I went to a church of england school, and as a child, yes, I did believe in God. I also believed in the tooth fairy, and Santa Claus. When I reached my teenage years, I stopped caring about religion, but I was still troubled by questions of right, wrong and what happens after death.
Now, as an adult, I can confidently say I am an atheist. Not because of any "le epic dawkins owns christcucks" compilation, but because I have read the bible, I have talked to christians and pastors, and I have found their answers to be unsatisfactory or built on shaky premises.
Science is not by itself a refutation of God. Science is man's attempt to explains reality through what he can reasonably hypothesise, test and from there prove or disprove. It has so far shown itself to be mostly accurate, and that's why we have satellites, modern medicine and nuclear bombs. But a God by its very nature would be beyond comprehension or quantification, so it is futile to try and "disprove" through logic, because there is no reason for a God to constrain itself to man's limited understanding of such things.

that paranoia likely stems from two things. Guilt, and holding onto a (presumably) christian conception of god and spirituality.

These are very important things to work through. I can't say much on how to deal with guilt, but I suggest you look more carefully at your overall belief system, in particular your beliefs regarding god.

Most atheists do not "lack a belief in god or gods". They define "god" in a specific way, usually heavily influenced by christianity, and reject the existence of such a being, thereby believing themselves to be atheists without having uncovered false beliefs they still hold.

"God" has no unified definition. There are numerous interpretations of this concept and even people within the same church will disagree about some pretty serious aspects of their god.

A god, in the simplest terms, is any entity or force that is distinctly more powerful than a human being in some regard. It is a classification of POWER. A human is a god in the eyes of a dog. An advanced alien would be as a god in the eyes of a human.

To lack a belief in a god or gods is to denounce this inherent truth. Pantheists believe the universe to be God. No atheist can rationally refute this beyond asserting their OWN definition of god. The question isn't whether "god or gods" exist. They do. The question is 'what is their nature'.

Focus on that issue. This will, at least, help you dismantle false beliefs you have regarding god (and hell). And working through this question can potentially help you work through things like guilt. The concept of "god" is, at the very least, a powerful tool that humans can use to help guide them towards higher ideals. Atheism is just the stepping stone to break free from dogmatic interpretations of the Divine; it is not the end goal.

lighting can make a big difference. not only are the shadows of a dark room going to hide a lot of your flaws and simplify the amount of detail you're looking at, but bathroom lighting is notoriously unflattering - specifically because it's usually very bright and brings out every detail, which not only also brings out flaws but is also just overwhelming to look at, and you miss the forest for the trees.
simplification of detail afforded by less light allows you to focus on your actual facial features. photographers will have very controlled lighting setups for this reason, and painters will be particular about where they do and don't paint detail. it's also why date spots like restaurants tend to have warm, lowish lighting, because it's more flattering.

>>28035213
>My boyfriend of 6 years is taking advantage of me because we didn't get rings and throw a party. My trust in him is forfeit with this comment.
That wasn't what I said. We can both hope that your current relationship works out as well as it seems to be going while still recognizing that other ways of doing things are better at protecting against risk and selecting for good-natured men.

>6 years of commitment
Marriage is the commitment. Even if you're in one of the few areas that has common-law marriage, you have distinctly fewer protections and rights because he isn't actually committed to you. He can walk out at any time with little to no formal consequences. Whether he would is beside the point. If he CAN, then he isn't committed.

What you're doing is just rationalization after the fact--yes, many people won't actually take advantage of you if you're in a situation without commitment. That you were with your bf for this long shows that he most likely isn't (although complacency of guys who are content to never marry is another issue), but the point is that he COULD have, and the only way you found out was by risking the worst. That's why someone considering getting into a relationship shouldn't do what you did--they should commit first, which removes almost all the risk of getting used.

It's also better for minimizing the risk of divorce (you said you fear a future break-up or divorce). Even controlling for religion, people who wait until marriage divorce less and have happier marriages. And then there's the logical reason that committing before doing anything sexual makes it much likelier that you only give yourself to your life partner--not a bad approach for a romantic.
Point being, there isn't any good reason not to wait if you care about either monogamy or relationship quality. Most people don't because of low impulse control, never seriously considering it as an option because of how normalized commitmentless sex is, or both.
